title: Apple Shouldn’t Buy Disney. Here’s Why.
text:
Text size

In Disney CEO Bob Iger’s new book, The Ride of a Lifetime, he makes the comment that his company might have merged with Apple if Steve Jobs were still alive. There is logic in the idea; you may remember that Jobs was once Disney’s largest shareholder, the result of the 2006 Disney acquisition of Pixar.

In a blog post, media analysts Rich Greenfield, Brandon Ross, and Mark Kelley from the new research firm Lightshed Partners engage in a thought experiment: Could the two giant companies still come together and live happily ever after?

“We understand why Disney and Iger would have wanted Apple to buy Disney, as it would have been the perfect ‘fairy tale’ ending to Iger’s run as Chairman and CEO of Disney,” they write. “Think about it from Disney’s perspective: build up the world’s most prized collection of content, brands and franchises and sell it to one of the world’s most innovative technology companies that understands how to marry together hardware and software (content) better than any other company.”

And then they proceed to blow up the idea, offering a list of seven reasons why Apple (ticker: AAPL) is unlikely to be interested in buying Disney (DIS).

1. Cord-cutting. Buying Disney would make Apple one of world’s largest owners of cable networks—plus a major broadcast network in ABC. The analysts note that Apple CEO Tim Cook has spoken repeatedly about “the legacy bundle breaking down at an accelerating pace.”

2. Legacy film-release window. They note that Disney is committed to the old-school theatrical release window for new feature films, “whereas Apple is focused on breaking legacy windowing.”

3. Complex legacy licensing. Past licensing deals slow Disney’s ability to offer streaming network Disney+ globally “and makes Hulu even harder to expand overseas.” HBO has to pay cable rights to the films from Disney’s newly acquired Fox unit for the next few years.

4. Regional sports rights. The analysts argue that it makes far more sense for Apple to spend on original programming than to own “absurdly expensive” regional sports programming with limited reach.

5. Ambitious creatives will still work for Apple. “Given the size of Apple’s balance sheet to finance original programming and their massive global installed base to promote the service to, we expect Hollywood talent/projects will want to work with Apple, regardless of whether they acquire a major studio,” they write.

6. Lack of interest in targeted advertising. The analysts note that while Disney is increasingly focused on advanced solutions to better target advertising across their linear and digital platforms, Apple is trying to make it more difficult for users of their devices to be tracked and targeted with ads.

7. Theme parks and consumer products a bad fit. “It is difficult to understand why Apple would want to be making toy lightsabers and princess outfits to sell at retail,” they write.

The analysts conclude: “We simply do not believe an Apple acquisition of Disney should or will occur.”

Write to Eric J. Savitz at eric.savitz@barrons.com
description: Media analysts Rich Greenfield, Brandon Ross, and Mark Kelley engage in a thought experiment: Could the two giant companies still come together and live happily ever after?
